text: The artist Wang Chien-chang's inscription relates that he painted this work for his friend Kung Wei-liu in 1650 when Kung acquired Wen Chia's version of the <I>P'i-p'a hsing ("Ode to the Pipa"), a famous poem written here in standard script and mounted directly above Wang's painting. Wen Chia was the second son of Wen Cheng-ming and, like his father, was an important Wu school calligrapher and painter. This famous Tang poem, called <I>Song of the Lute<I>, composed by the poet, Po Chu-i (772-846) is one of the great poems of Chinese literature. Wen Chia painted and inscribed several versions of his subject. Here, most likely influenced by a Wen Chia prototype, Wang illustrates the climax of the tale wherein the narrator thinks longingly of the pleasures of the capital (Ch'ang-an) as he listens with a friend to a former courtesan playing the bent-neck lute on a boat cast in autumn moon light. This classic literati painting typifies the Wu-school preference for small scale, lightly colored ink landscapes, lengthy inscriptions, and literary themes.
title: Ode to the P'i-p'a, or Song of the Lute
